existing_custody_order.reasoning: Complaint expressly alleges an existing Probate & Family Court custody/visitation order entered April 15, 2019 awarding primary physical custody to Petitioner and limited short visits to Respondent (¶2.1; ¶4.1).

specific_modification_sought.reasoning: Complaint seeks concrete changes: authorization of appropriate overnight/overnight sleepover parenting time for Father (including phased overnights leading to regular weekend overnights and selected weeknight overnights) and adjusted weekday parenting time to minimize school-night pick-ups/drop-offs and preserve homework/bedtime routines (¶8.2(a)–(b); ¶5.2(a)–(d)). While not listing minute-by-minute times, it identifies the substantive modifications requested.

material_substantial_change.reasoning: Complaint pleads multiple factual changes since 2019 that bear on the child’s welfare: the child is now 8 and in full‑time school with changed developmental and scheduling needs; the Father now has separate adequate housing with a bedroom for the child (contrasting the housing facts underlying the 2019 denial of overnights); current short visits cause school‑night disruption and fatigue; and the child and both parents desire adjusted parenting time (¶5.1–5.3; ¶5.2(a)–(d)). These factual allegations sufficiently plead a material and substantial change.

best_interests_of_child.reasoning: Complaint alleges the requested modification would promote the child’s best interests by reducing disruption to sleep/homework routines, promoting continuity and schooling stability, fostering a healthy parent‑child relationship with Father in adequate housing, and is supported by mutual agreement of the parents; it also cites the relevant best‑interest factors the Court must consider (¶6.1–6.3).
